nihexporter

Jay Hesselberth jay.hesselberth@gmail.com

2016-12-31

Overview

The nihexporter package provides the following tables of data:

  • projects has information about projects in each fiscal year, keyed by project.num
  • org_info has information about project organizations
  • project_orgs links applications to organizations
  • project_pis links PI information to a project
  • publinks table links PubMed IDs to project.num
  • publications links project IDs to PubMed IDs
  • patents links patent IDs to project IDs

See the documentation in the R package for more information about each table.

The package also has several precomputed variables and tables that enable quick and easy exploratory analysis:

  • nih.institutes: Two-letter format for 27 NIH institutes
  • project_io: This table contains pre-computed values for overall project cost (project.cost), as well as the number of publications (n.pubs) and patents (n.patents) associated with each project.

Examples

Many of the examples generate project numbers that you can use to look up project specifics in NIH REPORTER. We use the amazing dplyr, ggplot2 and knitr packages to manipulate and plot the data.

Award amounts

The fy.cost column from the projects table has many NA values. You need to use na.rm in aggregation functions to ensure robust handling of these values.

Let’s look at spending over time for NIGMS in years that have such data:

cost.over.time <- projects %>%
  select(institute, fy.cost, fiscal.year) %>%
  filter(institute == 'GM') %>%
  group_by(fiscal.year, institute) %>%
  summarize(yearly.cost = sum(fy.cost, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  filter(yearly.cost > 0)

cost.over.time %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = fiscal.year, y = yearly.cost)) +
  geom_line()

Spending at NIGMS

Let’s look at WHERE the money is going. This example illustrates linking of the project and project.orgs tables via the org.duns column.

money.per.institution <- projects %>%
  filter(activity == 'R01') %>%
  left_join(project_orgs) %>%
  select(org.duns, fiscal.year, fy.cost) %>%
  group_by(org.duns, fiscal.year) %>%
  summarise(total.award.billions = sum(fy.cost, na.rm = TRUE) / 1e9) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(total.award.billions)) %>%
  left_join(org_info) %>%
  select(fiscal.year, org.name, total.award.billions)

money.per.institution %>%
  head(10) %>% knitr::kable()
fiscal.year org.name total.award.billions
2009 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2972806
2010 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2929498
2004 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2892175
2011 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2863747
2005 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2781270
2012 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2739458
2006 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2708518
2007 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2684021
2003 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2661683
2015 JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY 0.2658217

One can also identiy PIs that have accrued large project dollars.

money.per.pi <- projects %>%
  filter(activity == 'R01') %>%
  select(project.num, fy.cost) %>%
  group_by(project.num) %>%
  summarise(total.award.millions = sum(fy.cost, na.rm = TRUE) / 1e6) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(total.award.millions)) %>%
  left_join(project_pis) %>%
  filter(pi.id != '') %>%
  group_by(pi.id) %>%
  summarise(pi.millionaire = sum(total.award.millions)) %>%
  arrange(desc(pi.millionaire))  
## Warning in left_join_impl(x, y, by$x, by$y, suffix$x, suffix$y): joining
## character vector and factor, coercing into character vector
money.per.pi %>%
  head(10) %>% knitr::kable()
pi.id pi.millionaire

6719627 1184.5336
1858142 996.0695
1862760 983.2956
8802713 713.6060
8187946 651.5645
1889062 585.5148
7733544 547.3865
1960402 531.2409
1862204 530.0165

Productivity

In order to measure the “return”" on the money the NIH invests in the research enterprise, we can measure scholarly output (i.e., publications) per dollar invested.

Here we identify th highest performing grants outside of the R01 category. Much has been made of the wasteful spending outside of investigator-initiated research. Here we can see that this is not always the case.

high.perf.not.r01 <- projects %>%
  filter(activity != 'R01') %>%
  group_by(project.num) %>%
  summarise(overall.cost = sum(fy.cost, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  filter(overall.cost > 1e6) %>%
  left_join(publinks) %>%
  filter(!is.na(pmid)) %>%
  group_by(project.num, overall.cost) %>%
  summarize(n.pubs = n()) %>%
  mutate(cost.per.pub = overall.cost / n.pubs) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(cost.per.pub)

high.perf.not.r01 %>%
  head(10) %>%
  kable()
project.num overall.cost n.pubs cost.per.pub
P30CA007175 2449282 719 3406.512
P30DK025295 2564892 691 3711.855
TL1RR024978 1306006 351 3720.815
P30MH030929 1710028 443 3860.108
P30MH031302 1045586 266 3930.774
P01CA018221 2727397 692 3941.325
P01NS010828 1390846 347 4008.202
P41RR001008 1506034 368 4092.484
C06RR015455 2000000 415 4819.277
R37MH042228 1328787 257 5170.377

The highest performer has 719 publications at a cost of 3406.511822 dollars per publication. Here are the Pubmed IDS of some of those publications:

Here we quantitate the return on R01 investment and identify the most expensive publications, in grant dollars. One might argue that grants with higher cost.per.pub are less good investments.

costly.pubs.r01 <- projects %>%
  filter(activity == 'R01') %>%
  group_by(project.num) %>%
  summarise(overall.cost = sum(fy.cost, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  left_join(publinks) %>%
  filter(!is.na(pmid)) %>%
  group_by(project.num, overall.cost) %>%
  summarize(n.pubs = n()) %>%
  mutate(cost.per.pub = overall.cost / n.pubs) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(cost.per.pub))
## Warning in left_join_impl(x, y, by$x, by$y, suffix$x, suffix$y): joining
## character vector and factor, coercing into character vector
costly.pubs.r01 %>%
  head(10) %>%
  knitr::kable()

R01HL084568 10227118 1 10227118

Duration

I am always impressed at how long people keep their grants. Let’s identify the longest running R01 projects. This leverages date manipulation with lubridate.

long.grants <- projects %>%
  filter(activity == 'R01') %>%
  select(project.num, project.start, project.end) %>%
  group_by(project.num) %>%
  summarize(longest.run = max(project.end) - min(project.start)) %>%
  arrange(desc(longest.run)) %>%
  mutate(in.years = as.numeric(longest.run) / 365)

long.grants %>%
  head(10) %>%
  knitr::kable()
project.num longest.run in.years
R01HL009610 18627 days 51.03288
R01HL013629 17166 days 47.03014
R01HD008188 16282 days 44.60822
R01DC005259 15855 days 43.43836
R01CA020525 15794 days 43.27123
R01GM013306 15705 days 43.02740
R01HL016037 15673 days 42.93973
R01CA013202 15644 days 42.86027
R01CA019033 15614 days 42.77808
R01DK013499 15462 days 42.36164
